results.title: Bread is life
results.brief_description: The story of the Bread Research Institute of the CSIRO and what it does including: analysing flour samples and experimenting with proportion of gluten in the flour mix; experimenting with machines for making bread; methods of storing flour; analysing faulty loaves and offering advice to improve quality.

results.title: Branding
results.brief_description: If you must brand, brand as lightly and as small as possible - this Wool Board film shows the woolgrower the financial loss caused, and the damage done to Australian-grown wool by the practice of branding sheep, stressing that the extra costs involved in removing brands before the wool is manufactured into cloth are inevitably passed back to growers and to the public. Narrated by Keith Eden.

Narrated by Keith Eden.

Narrated by Keith Eden.

results.title: Branded Si-Ro-Mark
results.creator_credit: Frank Land and Australian Wool Board
results.brief_description: Each year, great damage is done to the Australian wool clip by branding fluids. At wool sales, the price for marked wool decreases and in scouring and milling processes later, it is impossible to remove all the dirty wool, resulting in the needless waste of finished woollen goods. The CSIRO has developed an accurable and permanent branding fluid, “Si-Ro-Mark” and its wide-spread use to replace tar, sump-oil and other unsatisfactory fluids is advocated, not only in the interests of the grower but also the Australian wool and woollen textile industry as a whole.

results.brief_description: A report on the building of the giant, eight-engine Brabazon air liner, from its conception as an idea to the time of its flight in Septpember 1949. Commentary by John Mills.

results.title: Boys on film 3: Beyond gravity. Bad news bachelors. Resonance
results.creator_credit: James Wallace Productions, Realworld Pictures and Resonance Films
results.brief_description: Three short films from Australia and New Zealand featuring gay male characters. “Bad news bachelors” Set in Sydney, this short film follows thirty-something Stuart as he roams the city’s cafes, bars and cruising areas looking for a man to love but finding only sex with a series of likeable men - none of whom offer the likelihood of a relationship. “Resonance” This short experimental dance film opens with a vicious gay bashing, then pieces together the relationship between the victim, the basher and his girlfriend. Homophobia and misogyny are linked in the character of the basher. The plot is deliberately ambiguous. The basher resembles the martial arts instructor who is the rescuer of the victim. Gesture and dance are used as a form of interior monologue exploring the way this act of violence resonates through the lives of the characters. “Beyond Gravity”: Richard spends his time fantasising about outerspace and the cosmos, an activity which antagonises friends and family. Then one day he meets Johnny, a handsome Italian man, with an enormous appetite for life, who offers him love and an escape from the monotony of work. This short New Zealand film is a joyous celebration of the love between two eccentrics. It is also a refreshingly matter-of-fact and comic treatment of a romance between two men who both have their sights aimed firmly amongst the stars.
results.title_for_label: Boys on film 3: Beyond gravity. Bad news bachelors. Resonance

results.title: Bow bells
results.creator_credit: Anthony Simmons, Leon Clore and Harlequin Productions
results.brief_description: In “The London Spy”, Ned Ward’s delightful account of low life in the 18th Century, we are told how “the joyful alarm of Bow Bells call’d the weary apprentices from their work to unhitch their folded shutters and batten up their shops till next morning”. This is the atmosphere evoked by this film presenting faces, streets, buildings around the dock-yards of London’s East End. There is no commentary: the photographed scenes are accompanied by satirically matched snatches of music hall songs.
